text:
Yeah, sorry for criticizing it for not being something it wasn't intended to be...I've also read through the Wrangling/Viz notebook. My notes mostly focus on wrangling, although I get that's not really the most important part of the notebook.

* Maybe worth emphasizing in the d3.csv() section that D3 has a lot of functionality outside of rendering visual elements. I think coming from data work in R or Python, people associate D3 with viz, so they expect its API to map to what viz libraries do in those languages. (I say "people", but mean "me".)
* A minor point: I'm not sure about Pandas, but a tidy dataframe in R is a technically a list of column variables, not a list of row observations like the typical data array in js, although in practice you don't really ever think about it.
* I really like the comparison between map/filter and list comprehensions. The 1-1 translations are always great (I know you have a whole other notebook full of them). Consider including the Altair code that produces the equivalent of the vega-lite scatterplot.
* Just an aside, as I've tried to do a little wrangling in js recently, this pattern has been useful: `data.map(x => ({...x, newVar: expr}))`
* Dataforge (haven't used it) might be worth mentioning as the most Pandas-like option. <http://js4ds.org/#s:dataforge>
* I think the tutorial would flow better if the first chart you plot uses transformed data, rather than just the csv. Taking grouped counts and sums is a good realistic wrangling task.
* Not sure it fits here, but I could see Math.sum(1,2,3) in js being confusing coming from python's sum([1,2,3]).
* The part about getting Observable charts back into Pythonland is great. Definitely mention at the beginning that's where the tutorial is going.
* And I saved my lamest gripe for last: iris is a boring dataset.

text:
<@UE3KC0VK6> .. Do your customers want to do more than reports? So to make it easy to store and update  information as well as create reports, you could add something like  <https://pouchdb.com/>

Then things like this would work:
```localStorage.setItem('name','Chris');```
let myName = localStorage.getItem('name');

No need for POST statements. No need for custom server side code.  For the end user, this would be a simpler solution.

This also opens up the option of people working off line, and the data syncing after they are back online.

text: Got it, that's a neat thought! I might try it in a notebook. There's no good integrated persistent state solution yet, similar to Jupyter notebook users have to choose their own. This would be a cool one to use, but as you say it would be slicker if we provided the backend.
